contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox mountain | name = Kanjut Sar | photo = Kanjut Sar.jpg | photo_caption = Kanjut Sar (background centre) | elevation_m = 7760 | elevation_ref = <ref name=peaklist/><br /><small>[[List of highest mountains|Ranked 26th]] | prominence_m = 1660 | prominence_ref = <ref name=peaklist>{{cite web|url=http://www.peaklist.org/WWlists/ultras/karakoram.html|title=Karakoram and India/Pakistan Himalayas Ultra-Prominences|publisher=peaklist.org|accessdate=2010-08-05}}</ref> | range = [[Hispar Muztagh]], [[Karakoram]] | listing = [[Ultra prominent peak|Ultra]] | location = [[Gilgit-Baltistan]], [[Pakistan]] | map = Pakistan | map_size = 250 | label_position = left | lat_d = 36 | lat_m = 12 | lat_s = 18 | lat_NS = N | long_d= 75 | long_m= 25 | long_s= 06 | long_EW= E | coordinates_ref = <ref name=peaklist/> | first_ascent = 1959 by Camillo Pellissier | easiest_route = snow/ice climb }} '''Kanjut Sar''' is a [[mountain]] located in the [[Hispar Muztagh]], a subrange of the [[Karakoram]] [[mountain range]]. It lies within the [[Gilgit-Baltistan]] province of [[Pakistan]]. It is the [[List of highest mountains|26th highest]] mountain on Earth and the [[List of mountains in Pakistan|11th highest]] in Pakistan. Kanjut Sar consists of two peaks: * Kanjut Sar I at {{convert|7760|m|ft|0}}. * Kanjut Sar II, to the south east of I, at {{convert|6831|m|ft|0|abbr=on}}. Kanjut Sar I was first climbed in 1959 by Camillo Pellissier, member of an [[Italy|Italian]] expedition directed by [[Guido Monzino]]. In 2010 Russian-American expedition attempted to climb on the Eastern Ridge of Kanjut Sar and reached 7450 m, turning in bad weather. {{citation needed|date=August 2010}} ==See also== * [[List of highest mountains|Highest mountains of the world]] * [[List of Ultras of the Western Himalayas]] * [[List of mountains in Pakistan]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://bbs.keyhole.com/ubb/showthreaded.php/Cat/0/Number/420123/an/0/page/0#420123 Northern Pakistan - highly detailed placemarks of towns, villages, peaks, glaciers, rivers and minor tributaries in Google Earth] [[Category:Mountains of Pakistan]] [[Category:Seven-thousanders]]
